hed: Interactive: Do you know what you’re buying when you pay to download books, movies, and games?

intro.value: Last year Americans bought TKTK digital ebooks—about TK% of the total book market. Most of those buyers probably understood the obvious ways that ebooks are different from regular books. You can’t put them on a shelf to show off your erudition, scribble philosophical asides in the margins, or lose them under your bed. However, there are other, much less obvious, ways that digital books—and movies, games, and other digital media—are different from physical copies. Before we explain how and why, let’s test your knowledge about the things you buy:

question: If I buy the ebook on this page...

rights.text: I can give it away as a gift.
I can transfer it to any device that I own.
I can lend it to a friend.
I can leave it to my children in my will.
I can make a copy of it for yourself.

study.value: The questions you just answered are based on a study by Aaron Perzanowski and Chris Jay Hoofnagle, legal scholars who study digital ownership. For their paper, "What We Buy When We Buy Now" (pdf), they presented this example, in a few variations, to hundreds of internet shoppers. Those shoppers consistently, and dramatically, overestimated what rights they acquired to digital content they purchased online.

body1_hed: How we gave up on ownership

body1.value: What it means to “own” something is a bit nebulous, but by most important measures, you don't truly own the digital media you buy online. Instead, you license it from the company that sells it to you. Those long-winded Terms of Service agreements—that you probably click through without reading—are your contract with the seller. That contract enumerates precisely what you are and are not allowed to do with the content you buy.

This is quite different from what happens when you buy a physical book. Your rights to a physical book are largely governed by personal property law. Once you buy it, it’s yours to resell, lend, or gift as you see fit. No matter what you do with it, you never need to get permission from the bookseller. Your rights to a digital book, on the other hand, are almost entirely defined by the contract you entered into when you agreed to the Terms of Service. In the case of Apple, Amazon, and other major digital vendors, you don’t retain any of the rights listed above.

Using contracts as a replacement for property law predates the web. It was originally created as a way for software companies to protect against users endlessly copying their products. At that time, in the 1970’s, laws were just beginning to be confronted by a first wave of intangible goods, such as software. Rather than wait around for courts to figure out how to adapt existing notions of property to digital products, companies instead began to license their software to their users. In doing so, they could require the user to sign a contract stating they wouldn’t copy it.

Decades have passed since the first software licenses were agreed to and the law remains largely the same.  Meanwhile, the world of intangible goods has expanded dramatically. Thanks to the new distribution channels enabled by the internet, we now routinely license books, movies, music, and games, in addition to software.

At the same time software itself has become an indispensible part of many things we are used to thinking of as personal property. Even before the “internet of things” we were already putting software in our cars, phones, cameras, thermostats, and baby monitors. Typically, the person who buys those items doesn’t own that software. Consequently those things are, in a very real sense, not ours. Sure, you own the physical car body, but you only license the software that starts the engine. The car is entirely useless without it.

In both cases—digital media and software-enabled devices—the effect has been the same: Contracts are coming to govern an ever larger slice of our lives. Companies, therefore, increasingly dictate what we are and are not allowed to do. No amount of congressional action will allow give you the right to resell your copy an ebook, because you explicitly signed that right away when you agreed to the terms of service. (Even if you didn’t read them.) What’s more, if you violate any of the terms, the seller can simply take the book away from you. This might sound far-fetched, but it has happened before. In TKTK Amazon reached out and deleted copies of George Orwell’s 1984 from customers’ Kindle readers.

body2.value: Thus far, the debate over whether or not we should own our digital things has overshadowed by conversations about piracy and sustainable business models. Consumers have largely been spared the pain of losing anything they really cared about. In fact, in light of the incredible value offered by new streaming services, it may seem to be a golden age for consumer choice.

However, there is reason to believe that this issue may be bubbling to the service. As the things we buy—and create—are increasingly digital, the issue of what we actually own is bubbling up in unexpected places.

Consider, for example, owners of John Deere tractors, who have discovered that the contract they sign when they purchase a new tractor includes a software license. The terms of that license prevent third-party mechanics from using diagnostic software to determine why the tractor is broken. As a result, no matter how tech savvy a farmer’s neigbhorhood mechanic might be, he has no choice but to use John Deere’s, often much more expensive, certified mechanics. TKTK: can he sell it?

The confusion over what we own is, at least in part a question of language. Although we don’t actually “buy” digital content, sellers continue to use that language. Perzanowski and Hoofnagle’s tested a variation of the store replaced the “Buy now” button with one labelled  “License now” and found that consumers more accurately predicted the rights they were conferred. A third test explicitly stated the rights consumers acquired, which performed even better, though in no case were consumers uniformly accurate. (TK: vet all this)

As technology permeates more and more of our lives—and as our lives are increasingly lived inside digital worlds—it’s inevitable that this issue will become more pressing. However, that doesn’t means there are any obvious solutions. Scholars such as Perzanowski believe that the right solution is a restoration of full property rights to digital goods. This presents a number of technical and economic challenges, but realistically the greatest challenge is political. The lobbying efforts against any such legal realignment would undoubtedly be widespread and incredibly well bank-rolled.

Perhaps the most plausible mechanism for reform is the creation of a 21st century consumer rights movement. Just as the consumer rights movement of the 20th century sought to protect buyers from unscrupulous car manufacturers and false advertising, a modern equivalent could watchdog the worst abuses of consumer contracts and to restore important legal protections, such as the right to reverse-engineer the software in our devices so they can be repaired or repurposed.
